Use: Kimsuky has added accounts to specific groups with net localgroup . [12]
Kimsuky has registered domains to spoof targeted organizations and trusted third parties. [10] [13] [5] [3] [4] [12]
Kimsuky has purchased hosting servers with virtual currency and prepaid cards. [12]
Kimsuky has hosted content used for targeting efforts via web services such as Blogspot. [14]
Kimsuky has used modified versions of PHProxy to examine web traffic between the victim and the accessed website. [5]
Kimsuky has used HTTP GET and POST requests for C2. [14]

Technique: Application Layer Protocol: File Transfer Protocols
Use: Kimsuky has used FTP to download additional malware to the target machine. [15]
Kimsuky has used e-mail to send exfiltrated data to C2 servers. [5]

Technique: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
Use: Kimsuky has used QuickZip to archive stolen files before exfiltration. [14]

Technique: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Custom Method
Use: Kimsuky has used RC4 encryption before exfil. [16]

Technique: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Use: Kimsuky has placed scripts in the startup folder for persistence and modified the HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce Registry key. [16] [5] [17] [14] [12]
Kimsuky has used Google Chrome browser extensions to infect victims and to steal passwords and cookies. [9] [6]
Kimsuky has executed a variety of PowerShell scripts. [1] [5] [14] [12]

Technique: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell
Use: Kimsuky has executed Windows commands by using cmd and running batch scripts. [14] [12]

Technique: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Visual Basic
Use: Kimsuky has used Visual Basic to download malicious payloads. [10] [15] [17] [14] Kimsuky has also used malicious VBA macros within maldocs disguised as forms that trigger when a victim types any content into the lure. [14]
Kimsuky has used a macOS Python implant to gather data as well as MailFetcher.py code to automatically collect email data. [5] [12]
Kimsuky has used JScript for logging and downloading additional tools. [15] [5]
Kimsuky has compromised email accounts to send spearphishing e-mails. [15] [4]
Kimsuky has compromised legitimate sites and used them to distribute malware. [12]
Kimsuky has created accounts with net user . [12]

Technique: Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
Use: Kimsuky has created new services for persistence. [16] [5]

Technique: Credentials from Password Stores: Credentials from Web Browsers
Use: Kimsuky has used browser extensions including Google Chrome to steal passwords and cookies from browsers. Kimsuky has also used Nirsoft's WebBrowserPassView tool to dump the passwords obtained from victims. [9] [5] [6] [14]
Kimsuky has collected Office, PDF, and HWP documents from its victims. [16] [14]
Kimsuky has staged collected data files under C:\Program Files\Common Files\System\Ole DB\ . [5] [14]
Kimsuky has decoded malicious VBScripts using Base64. [14]
Kimsuky created and used a mailing toolkit to use in spearphishing attacks. [15]
Kimsuky has developed its own unique malware such as MailFetch.py for use in operations. [12] [14]
Kimsuky has used tools such as the MailFetch mail crawler to collect victim emails (excluding spam) from online services via IMAP. [12]
Kimsuky has set auto-forward rules on victim's e-mail accounts. [5]
Kimsuky has created social media accounts to monitor news and security trends as well as potential targets. [12]
Kimsuky has created email accounts for phishing operations. [12]

Technique: Event Triggered Execution: Change Default File Association
Use: Kimsuky has a HWP document stealer module which changes the default program association in the registry to open HWP documents. [16]
Kimsuky has exfiltrated data over its C2 channel. [16] [14]

Technique: Exfiltration Over Web Service: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
Use: Kimsuky has exfiltrated stolen files and data to actor-controlled Blogspot accounts. [14]
Kimsuky has exploited various vulnerabilities for initial access, including Microsoft Exchange vulnerability CVE-2020-0688. [12]
Kimsuky has used RDP to establish persistence. [5]
Kimsuky has the ability to enumerate all files and directories on an infected system. [16] [14] [12]

Technique: Gather Victim Identity Information: Email Addresses
Use: Kimsuky has collected valid email addresses that were subsequently used in spearphishing campaigns. [4]

Technique: Gather Victim Identity Information: Employee Names
Use: Kimsuky has collected victim employee name information. [12]
Kimsuky has collected victim organization information including but not limited to organization hierarchy, functions, press releases, and others. [12]
Kimsuky has run reg add ‘HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\SpecialAccounts\UserList’ /v to hide a newly created user. [12]
Kimsuky has used an information gathering module that will hide an AV software window from the victim. [14]

Technique: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
Use: Kimsuky has been observed turning off Windows Security Center and can hide the AV software window from the view of the infected user. [16] [14]

Technique: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Use: Kimsuky has been observed disabling the system firewall. [16]

Kimsuky has deleted the exfiltrated data on disk after transmission. Kimsuky has also used an instrumentor script to terminate browser processes running on an infected system and then delete the cookie files on disk. [16] [14] [12]
Kimsuky has manipulated timestamps for creation or compilation dates to defeat anti-forensics. [3]
Kimsuky has downloaded additional scripts, tools, and malware onto victim systems. [17] [14]
Kimsuky has used a PowerShell-based keylogger as well as a tool called MECHANICAL to log keystrokes. [1] [16] [5] [6] [14] [12]
Kimsuky has sent internal spearphishing emails for lateral movement after stealing victim information. [12]
Kimsuky has disguised services to appear as benign software or related to operating system functions. [5]

Technique: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Use: Kimsuky has renamed malware to legitimate names such as ESTCommon.dll or patch.dll . [18]
Kimsuky has modified Registry settings for default file associations to enable all macros and for persistence. [5] [17] [14] [12]
Kimsuky has used a proprietary tool to intercept one time passwords required for two-factor authentication. [12]
Kimsuky has used the Nirsoft SniffPass network sniffer to obtain passwords sent over non-secure protocols. [5] [6]

Kimsuky has obfuscated binary strings including the use of XOR encryption and Base64 encoding. [10] [15] Kimsuky has also modified the first byte of DLL implants targeting victims to prevent recognition of the executable file format. [14]
Kimsuky has packed malware with UPX. [4]
Kimsuky has obtained and used tools such as Nirsoft WebBrowserPassVIew, Mimikatz , and PsExec . [6] [14]
Kimsuky has obtained exploit code for various CVEs. [12]
Kimsuky has gathered credentials using Mimikatz and ProcDump. [5] [6] [12]
Kimsuky has used emails containing Word, Excel and/or HWP (Hangul Word Processor) documents in their spearphishing campaigns. [9] [16] [10] [15] [3] [4] [14] [12]
Kimsuky has sent spearphishing emails containing a link to a document that contained malicious macros or took the victim to an actor-controlled domain. [1] [6] [12]
Kimsuky has used links in e-mail to steal account information. [15] [4] [12]
Kimsuky can gather a list of all processes running on a victim's machine. [14]
Kimsuky has used Win7Elevate to inject malicious code into explorer.exe. [16]
Kimsuky has used a file injector DLL to spawn a benign process on the victim's system and inject the malicious payload into it via process hollowing. [14]
Kimsuky has obtained specific Registry keys and values on a compromised host. [14]
Kimsuky has used a modified TeamViewer client as a command and control channel. [16] [17]
Kimsuky has used RDP for direct remote point-and-click access. [6]
Kimsuky has downloaded additional malware with scheduled tasks. [12]
Kimsuky has used Twitter to monitor potential victims and to prepare targeted phishing e-mails. [4]
Kimsuky has searched for vulnerabilities, tools, and geopolitical trends on Google to target victims. [12]
Kimsuky has searched for information on the target company's website. [12]
Kimsuky has used modified versions of open source PHP web shells to maintain access, often adding "Dinosaur" references within the code. [5]
Kimsuky has checked for the presence of antivirus software with powershell Get-CimInstance -Namespace root/securityCenter2 – classname antivirusproduct . [12]
Kimsuky has used Blogspot to host malicious content such as beacons, file exfiltrators, and implants. [14]
Kimsuky has signed files with the name EGIS CO,. Ltd.. [10]
Kimsuky has used mshta.exe to run malicious scripts on the system. [1] [5] [17] [12]
Kimsuky has executed malware with regsvr32s . [12]
Kimsuky has used rundll32.exe to execute malicious scripts and malware on a victim's network. [14]
Kimsuky has enumerated drives, OS type, OS version, and other information using a script or the "systeminfo" command. [16] [14]
Kimsuky has used ipconfig/all to gather network configuration information. [14]
Kimsuky has used an instrumentor script to gather the names of all services running on a victim's system. [14]
Kimsuky has used tools that are capable of obtaining credentials from saved mail. [6]

Technique: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Hash
Use: Kimsuky has used pass the hash for authentication to remote access software used in C2. [5]
Kimsuky has lured victims into clicking malicious links. [12]
Kimsuky has used attempted to lure victims into opening malicious e-mail attachments. [10] [15] [5] [3] [4] [14]
Kimsuky has used a tool called GREASE to add a Windows admin account in order to allow them continued access via RDP. [6]
Kimsuky has used Blogspot pages for C2. [14]
